sentence: Adversaries may exploit setuid and setgid permissions to escalate privileges by creating and executing a custom binary.
Adversaries may inject malicious SSH keys into the authorized_keys file to gain unauthorized access to systems.
Adversaries may attempt to create or modify system services to establish persistence on a compromised system.
Adversaries may attempt to escalate privileges by inserting malicious cron jobs into a MySQL database to modify the sudoers file.
Adversaries may create and execute malicious scripts to perform unauthorized actions on a system.
Adversaries may attempt to persist by creating malicious events or scripts that execute at system reboot.
Adversaries may modify user configuration files to execute commands automatically upon user login.
Adversaries may attempt to change file permissions to gain unauthorized access or control over files and directories.
Adversaries may attempt to make files difficult to discover by hiding them in directories and modifying system configurations to avoid detection.
Adversaries may disable or stop security tools to evade detection and hinder defenses.
Adversaries may delete or modify artifacts generated within systems to remove evidence of their presence or hinder defenses.
Adversaries may attempt to disable or tamper with auditing and logging mechanisms to remove evidence of their activities.
Adversaries may delete or modify log files to remove evidence of their presence or hinder defenses.
Adversaries may delete or modify command history to remove evidence of their presence or hinder defenses.
Adversaries may attempt to delete or modify log files to remove evidence of their presence or hinder defenses.
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate database user privileges and execute unauthorized SQL commands to remove evidence of their presence or hinder defenses.
Adversaries may replace or modify system binaries to disguise them and to execute malicious code or commands.
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate database entries and create or modify tables to masquerade them or to insert malicious data or commands.
Adversaries may insert malicious content into files and change their extensions to disguise them.
Adversaries may attempt to make an executable or file difficult to discover or analyze by encoding or otherwise obfuscating its contents on the system.
Adversaries may encrypt files to make them difficult to discover or analyze and then move them to another location.
Adversaries may attempt to download and install rootkits to gain unauthorized access and manipulate system configurations.
Adversaries may attempt to access and enumerate databases and tables to gather information about the system and its users.
Adversaries may gather information about the system and its configuration by reading files in the /proc directory.
Adversaries may attempt to gather information about user accounts by accessing the /etc/passwd file.
Adversaries may gather information about configuration files to understand the system setup and identify potential vulnerabilities.
Adversaries may copy sensitive files and system logs to a staging directory to exfiltrate data or gather information.
Adversaries may capture keystrokes to monitor user input and gather sensitive information.
Adversaries may attempt to inject malicious code into database tables to manipulate data or disrupt operations.
Adversaries may set up a reverse shell to establish a remote connection and gain unauthorized access to a system.
Adversaries may use SSH port forwarding to create tunnels for accessing internal services and bypassing network restrictions.
Adversaries may attempt to schedule tasks for execution on a system to persistently execute malicious commands or scripts.
Adversaries may attempt to delete or modify database users and tables to disrupt operations and remove evidence of their presence.
Adversaries may attempt to destroy or manipulate data within a database to disrupt operations or cause damage.
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate database entries to execute malicious commands or disrupt operations.
Adversaries may modify web content and configuration files to deface websites or alter their behavior.
Adversaries may attempt to destroy data and files on specific systems or in large numbers on a network to interrupt availability to systems, services, and network resources.
Adversaries may attempt to manipulate database entries to execute unauthorized commands or disrupt system operations.
Adversaries may attempt to stop or kill database services to disrupt availability and operations.
Adversaries may attempt to destroy data and files on a system to interrupt availability to systems and services.
